{"currentConversationId":"5d16c106-c735-417e-8b2d-6d534be8222b","agentExecutionMode":"manual","isPanelCollapsed":true,"displayedAnnouncements":[],"conversations":{"5d16c106-c735-417e-8b2d-6d534be8222b":{"id":"5d16c106-c735-417e-8b2d-6d534be8222b","name":"Built modular Java logging library
","createdAtIso":"2025-10-11T13:40:27.405Z","lastInteractedAtIso":"2025-10-27T16:15:53.732Z","chatHistory":[{"request_id":"d708ac46-41bf-4c7b-8185-93d5642a44b5","uuid":"8cc79dda-dd6a-479a-bb50-bd2ebcd9debe","chatItemType":"agentic-checkpoint-delimiter","status":"success","fromTimestamp":0,"toTimestamp":1760190027405,"seen_state":"unseen"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"a9be7817-1f56-4bc3-8003-e61031e275cf","timestamp":"2025-10-11T13:40:33.789Z","request_message":"Develop a basic logging library that can be used by applications to log messages. The library should handle message logging efficiently and reliably, offering basic configuration options.

Key Requirements:

● Driver Application should be able to Initialize the Library and log messages to the desired sink. ● Logger has the following capabilities- ○ Accepts messages from client(s) ○ A logger would have one or more sinks associated with it. ○ Supports defined message levels. ○ enriches message with current timestamp while directing message to a sink ○ Logger is initialized with a configuration eg:logger name, sink(s), buffer size. ○ Logger should support both sync and async logging. ■ For Async logger buffer size would determine the maximum inflight messages. ○ Messages must be ordered. Messages should reach the sink in the order they were sent. ○ Should support writes from multiple-threads. ○ There shouldn’t be any data loss. ● Sink: ○ There can be various types of sink (file, stdout, database). ○ Sink has a destination. ■ For this round you may create STDOUT sink, which would print the message to the console. ○ Sink has an associated log level. Any message with the level lower than the sink level should be discarded. ● Message ○ has content which is of type string ○ has a level associated with it ● Log Level ○ DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL ; in order of priority. ERROR has higher priority than INFO.

Sending messages

● Sink need not be mentioned while sending a message to the logger library. ● You specify message content and level while sending a message

Logger configuration (see sample below)

● Specifies all the details required to use the logger library. ● Library can accept one or more configuration for an application ● Example: ○ time format ○ logging level ○ sink type ○ Logger type sync/async ○ details required for sink (eg file location)); this depends on sink type.

Sample Config:

Ts_format: any format log_level:INFO logger_type:ASYNC buffer_size:25 sink_type:STDOUT

Sample Output Log Entry

03-01-2024-09-30-00 [INFO] This is a sample log message.

Expectations and Guidelines

Create the sample data yourself. You can put it into a file, test case or main driver program itself.
The code should be demo-able. Either by using the main driver program or test cases.
The code should be modular. The code should have the basic OO design. Please do not jam in the responsibilities of one class into another.
The code should be extensible. Wherever applicable, use interfaces and contracts between different methods. It should be easy to add/remove functionality without rewriting the entire codebase.
The code should handle edge cases properly and fail gracefully.
The code should be legible, readable and DRY.
Database integration is not required.
Please do not access the internet for anything EXCEPT syntax.
You are free to use the language and IDE of your choice.
The entire code should be your IF MORE CONTENT NEEDS TO BE ADDED USE THE str-replace-editor TOOL TO EDIT THE FILE AFTER IT HAS BEEN CREATED.", "path": "agent-ranking-lld/src/main/java/com/agentranking/RankingSystem.java", "file_content": "package com.agentranking;\n\nimport java.util.*;\nimport java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentHashMap;\nimport java.util.stream.Collectors;\n\n/**\n * Main ranking system that manages agents, ratings, and rankings.\n * Thread-safe implementation for concurrent access.\n */\npublic class RankingSystem {\n \n private final ConcurrentHashMap<String, Agent> agents;\n private final ConcurrentHashMap<String, AgentStats> agentStats;\n private final ConcurrentHashMap<String, Rating> ratings;\n private final Object rankingLock = new Object();\n \n public RankingSystem() {\n this.agents = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();\n this.agentStats = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();\n this.ratings = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();\n }\n \n /**\n * Registers a new agent in the system.\n */\n public void registerAgent(Agent agent) {\n if (agent == null) {\n throw new IllegalArgumentException(\"Agent cannot be null\");\n }\n \n agents.put(agent.getAgentId(), agent);\n agentStats.putIfAbsent(agent.getAgentId(), new AgentStats(agent.getAgentId()));\n }\n \n /**\n * Submits a rating for an agent.\n */\n public void submitRating(Rating rating) {\n if (rating == null) {\n throw new IllegalArgumentException(\"Rating cannot be null\");\n }\n \n String agentId = rating.getAgentId();\n \n // Check if agent exists\n if (!agents.containsKey(agentId)) {\n throw new IllegalArgumentException(\"Agent not found: \" + agentId);\n }\n \n // Store the rating\n ratings.put(rating.getRatingId(), rating);\n \n // Update agent statistics\n AgentStats stats = agentStats.get(agentId);\n if (stats != null) {\n stats.addRating(rating.getScore());\n }\n \n // Recalculate rankings\n updateRankings();\n }\n \n /**\n * Removes a rating from the system.\n */\n public void removeRating(String ratingId) {\n Rating rating = ratings.remove(ratingId);\n if (rating != null) {\n AgentStats stats = agentStats.get(rating.getAgentId());\n if (stats != null) {\n stats.removeRating(rating.getScore());\n }\n updateRankings();\n }\n }\n \n /**\n * Updates the rankings of all agents based on their average ratings.\n */\n private void updateRankings() {\n synchronized (rankingLock) {\n // Get all stats and sort them\n List<AgentStats> sortedStats = new ArrayList<>(agentStats.values());\n Collections.sort(sortedStats);\n \n // Assign ranks\n int rank = 1;\n for (AgentStats stats : sortedStats) {\n stats.setRank(rank++);\n }\n }\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets the current rank of an agent.\n */\n public int getAgentRank(String agentId) {\n AgentStats stats = agentStats.get(agentId);\n return stats != null ? stats.getRank() : -1;\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets the statistics for an agent.\n */\n public AgentStats getAgentStats(String agentId) {\n return agentStats.get(agentId);\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets an agent by ID.\n */\n public Agent getAgent(String agentId) {\n return agents.get(agentId);\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets the top N agents by ranking.\n */\n public List<AgentStats> getTopAgents(int n) {\n synchronized (rankingLock) {\n return agentStats.values().stream()\n .sorted()\n .limit(n)\n .collect(Collectors.toList());\n }\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets all agents sorted by rank.\n */\n public List<AgentStats> getAllAgentsByRank() {\n synchronized (rankingLock) {\n return agentStats.values().stream()\n .sorted()\n .collect(Collectors.toList());\n }\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets agents by department, sorted by rank.\n */\n public List<AgentStats> getAgentsByDepartment(String department) {\n synchronized (rankingLock) {\n return agentStats.values().stream()\n .filter(stats -> {\n Agent agent = agents.get(stats.getAgentId());\n return agent != null && department.equals(agent.getDepartment());\n })\n .sorted()\n .collect(Collectors.toList());\n }\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets the total number of agents.\n */\n public int getTotalAgents() {\n return agents.size();\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets the total number of ratings.\n */\n public int getTotalRatings() {\n return ratings.size();\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets all ratings for a specific agent.\n */\n public List<Rating> getAgentRatings(String agentId) {\n return ratings.values().stream()\n .filter(r -> r.getAgentId().equals(agentId))\n .sorted(Comparator.comparing(Rating::getTimestamp).reversed())\n .collect(Collectors.toList());\n }\n \n /**\n * Gets the average rating across all agents.\n */\n public double getSystemAverageRating() {\n return agentStats.values().stream()\n .filter(stats -> stats.getTotalRatings() > 0)\n .mapToDouble(AgentStats::getAverageRating)\n .average()\n .orElse(0.0);\n }\n \n /**\n * Clears all data from the system.\n */\n public void clear() {\n agents.clear();\n agentStats.clear();\n ratings.clear();\n }\n}\n"}","mcp_server_name":"","mcp_tool_name":""}},{"id":2,"type":5,"content":"","tool_use":{"tool_use_id":"toolu_vrtx_019BUxtmJomN538uETvpX3eE","tool_name":"save-file","input_json":"{"instructions_reminder": "file_content": "package com.agentranking;\n\nimport java.util.List;\n\n/**\n * Provides formatted views of the agent leaderboard.\n */\npublic class LeaderboardView {\n \n private final RankingSystem rankingSystem;\n \n public LeaderboardView(RankingSystem rankingSystem) {\n this.rankingSystem = rankingSystem;\n }\n \n /**\n * Displays the top N agents in a formatted table.\n */\n public String displayTopAgents(int n) {\n List<AgentStats> topAgents = rankingSystem.getTopAgents(n);\n \n StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();\n create a new module for the below interview question:
Find the closest Org for target Employees
a) Imagine you are the team that maintains the Atlassian employee directory. At Atlassian – there are multiple groups, and each can have one or more groups. Every employee is part of a group. You are tasked with designing a system that could find the closest common parent group giv a target set of employees in the organization.
b) The Atlassian hierarchy sometimes can have shared group across an org or employees shared across different groups – How will the code evolve n this case if the requirement is to provide ONE closest common group
c) The system now introduced 4 methods to update the structure of the hierarchy in the org. Includes 31 passing tests and comprehensive documentation including INTERVIEW_STRATEGY.md.

Both modules were successfully integrated into the parent POM, all tests passed (94 total tests across all modules), and the main README was updated to document the new modules.

## 2. Current Work

The user requested creation of a new module for an Atlassian interview question about finding the closest common parent group for employees in an organization hierarchy. The specific requirements were:

**Interview Question Parts:**
- a) Basic hierarchy with groups and subgroups
- b) Shared groups (employees in multiple groups, groups with multiple parents)
- c) Concurrent reads/writes with dynamic updates - system must handle updates in separate threads while getCommonGroupForEmployees is being called
- d) Flat hierarchy support (single level groups with no subgroups)

The assistant has created the **org-hierarchy-lld** module with:

**Completed:**

- Created Employee.java (immutable data class)
- Created Group.java (with support for multiple parents and children using ConcurrentHashMap.newKeySet())
- Created OrgHierarchy.java (main system with ReadWriteLock for thread safety)
- Created DriverApplication.java (comprehensive demo with 6 scenarios)
- Created OrgHierarchyTest.java (28 comprehensive tests)
- Created INTERVIEW_STRATEGY.md (complete 45-60 minute interview guide)

**Current Status:**
The module has been compiled successfully. The assistant was about to run the tests when the user requested this summary.

## 3. Key Technical Concepts

### Organization Hierarchy Module:
- **Lowest Common Ancestor (LCA) in DAG**: Algorithm to find closest common parent group
- **Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG)**: Hierarchy structure allowing multiple parents but no cycles
- **ReadWriteLock**: Java concurrency mechanism allowing multiple concurrent reads but exclusive writes
- **BFS (Breadth-First Search)**: Used to collect ancestors and traverse hierarchy
- **Thread Safety**: ConcurrentHashMap, ConcurrentHashMap.newKeySet(), ReadWriteLock
- **Cycle Detection**: Prevents cycles when adding parent-child relationships
- **Shared Groups**: Employees can be in multiple groups, groups can have multiple parents
- **Flat Hierarchy**: Support for single-level organization structures

### General Project Patterns:
- **Maven Multi-Module Project**: Parent POM with multiple child modules
- **Factory Pattern**: Used in rate limiter module
- **Builder Pattern**: Used in configuration objects
- **Immutable Objects**: Employee class is immutable
- **Thread-Safe Collections**: ConcurrentHashMap, ConcurrentHashMap.newKeySet()
- **JUnit 4**: Testing framework
- **Java 11**: Target version

## 4. Relevant Files and Code

### **org-hierarchy-lld/pom.xml**
- Maven configuration for the new module
- Dependencies: JUnit 4.13.2
- Exec plugin configured with mainClass: com.orghierarchy.DriverApplication

### **org-hierarchy-lld/src/main/java/com/orghierarchy/Employee.java**

- Fields: employeeId, name, email
- Validation in constructor
- Implements equals() and hashCode() based on employeeId

### **org-hierarchy-lld/src/main/java/com/orghierarchy/Group.java**
- Represents a group in the hierarchy
- Fields: groupId, name, employeeIds (Set), childGroupIds (Set), parentGroupIds (Set)
- Uses ConcurrentHashMap.newKeySet() for thread-safe collections
- Supports multiple parents (for shared groups scenario)
- Methods: addEmployee, removeEmployee, addChildGroup, removeChildGroup, addParentGroup, removeParentGroup

```java
public class Group {
 private final String groupId;
 private final String name;
 private final Set<String> employeeIds;
 private final Set<String> childGroupIds;
 private final Set<String> parentGroupIds; // For handling multiple parents
 
 public Group(String groupId, String name) {
 this.groupId = groupId;
 this.name = name;
 this.employeeIds = ConcurrentHashMap.newKeySet();
 this.childGroupIds = ConcurrentHashMap.newKeySet();
 this.parentGroupIds = ConcurrentHashMap.newKeySet();
 }
}
```

### **org-hierarchy-lld/src/main/java/com/orghierarchy/OrgHierarchy.java**
- Main system managing employees, groups, and hierarchy
- Data structures:
 - `ConcurrentHashMap<String, Employee> employees`
 - `ConcurrentHashMap<String, Group> groups`
 - `ConcurrentHashMap<String, Set<String>> employeeToGroupsMap` (supports employees in multiple groups)
 - `ReadWriteLock lock` for thread safety

**Key Methods:**
- **Write Operations** (use writeLock):
 - `addEmployee(Employee)`, `addGroup(Group)`
 - `addEmployeeToGroup(String, String)`
 - `addGroupToGroup(String childId, String parentId)` - with cycle detection
 - `removeEmployeeFromGroup(String, String)`
 - `moveEmployeeToGroup(String, String, String)`

- **Read Operations** (use readLock):
 - `getClosestCommonGroup(Set<String> employeeIds)` - main algorithm
 - `getGroupsForEmployee(String)`
 - `getEmployeesInGroup(String)`
 - `getAllEmployeesInGroupHierarchy(String)` - recursive

**Core Algorithm - getClosestCommonGroup:**
```java
public Group getClosestCommonGroup(Set<String> employeeIds) {
 lock.readLock().lock();
 try {
 // 1. Get all groups for each employee
 List<Set<String>> employeeGroupSets = new ArrayList<>();
 for (String empId : employeeIds) {
 Set<String> empGroups = employeeToGroupsMap.get(empId);
 employeeGroupSets.add(empGroups);
 }
 
 // 2. Find common direct groups
 Set<String> commonGroups = new HashSet<>(employeeGroupSets.get(0));
 for (int i = 1; i < employeeGroupSets.size(); i++) {
 commonGroups.retainAll(employeeGroupSets.get(i));
 }
 
 // 3. If common direct group exists, return it
 if (!commonGroups.isEmpty()) {
 return findGroupWithMinimumDepth(commonGroups);
 }
 
 // 4. BFS to find common ancestor
 return findLowestCommonAncestor(employeeGroupSets);
 } finally {
 lock.readLock().unlock();
 }
}
```

**Helper Methods:**
- `findLowestCommonAncestor()` - uses BFS to collect ancestors and find intersection
- `collectAncestors()` - BFS to collect all ancestors of a group
- `findGroupWithMinimumDepth()` - returns group closest to leaves
- `calculateDepth()` - calculates distance from root
- `wouldCreateCycle()` - prevents cycles in hierarchy
- `collectDescendants()` - collects all descendants for cycle detection

## 5. Problem Solving

**Successfully Solved:**
1. **Shared Groups Support**: Implemented using Set<String> for both parentGroupIds and employeeToGroupsMap, allowing employees to be in multiple groups and groups to have multiple parents.

2. **Thread Safety for Concurrent Reads/Writes**: Implemented using ReadWriteLock which allows:
 - Multiple concurrent reads (getClosestCommonGroup can be called by multiple threads)
 - Exclusive writes (dynamic updates are serialized)
 - Reads always reflect latest state

3. **Cycle Detection**: Implemented wouldCreateCycle() method that checks if adding a parent-child relationship would create a cycle by verifying if the parent is a descendant of the child.

4. **Flat Hierarchy Support**: Algorithm naturally handles flat hierarchies - returns common direct group if exists, otherwise returns null if no common parent.

5. **Finding Closest Common Group**: Implemented LCA algorithm using:
 - First check for common direct groups (O(N) intersection)
 - If none, use BFS to collect all ancestors for each employee's groups
 - Find intersection of ancestor sets
 - Return ancestor with minimum depth (closest to employees)

- Module compiled successfully: `mvn clean compile -pl org-hierarchy-lld` returned BUILD SUCCESS
- 4 source files compiled without errors

4. **Organization Hierarchy (org-hierarchy-lld)**: A system to find the closest common parent group for employees in an organization hierarchy, implementing Lowest Common Ancestor (LCA) algorithm in a DAG structure. This was a classic Atlassian interview question covering:
 - Part (a): Basic hierarchy with groups and subgroups

All modules include comprehensive documentation (README.md and INTERVIEW_STRATEGY.md), extensive test coverage, and demo applications. The total project had 181 tests passing across all 5 modules.

## 2. Current Work

The user requested creation of a new module for the **Commodity Prices** interview question:

**Problem Statement:**
- Given a stream of data points consisting of `<timestamp, commodityPrice>`
- Return the maxCommodityPrice at any point in time
- Timestamps can be out-of-order
- Duplicate timestamps should update the existing price
- Create an in-memory solution optimized for frequent reads and writes

**Work Completed:**

1. **Created module structure** (commodity-prices-lld/pom.xml):
 - Maven module configuration
 - JUnit 4.13.2 dependency
 - Exec plugin configured with mainClass: com.commodityprices.DriverApplication

2. **Created PriceDataPoint.java**:
 - Immutable data class representing `<timestamp, price>`
 - Implements Comparable (sorted by price descending, then timestamp ascending)
 - Validation for non-negative timestamp and price
 - Proper equals() and hashCode() implementation

3. **Created CommodityPriceTracker.java** - Main tracking system:
 - **Design**: Dual data structure approach for optimization
 - `ConcurrentHashMap<Long, Double>` for O(1) timestamp-to-price lookups
 - `TreeSet<PriceDataPoint>` for O(log N) insertions and O(1) max queries
 - `ReadWriteLock` for concurrent reads (multiple readers, exclusive writers)
 
 - **Key Methods**:
 - `update(timestamp, price)`: O(log N) - handles both new entries and updates
 - `getMaxPrice()`: O(1) - returns max price from TreeSet.first()
 - `getPriceAt(timestamp)`: O(1) - HashMap lookup
 - `getMaxPriceDataPoint()`: O(1) - returns full data point with max price
 - `remove(timestamp)`: O(log N) - removes from both structures
 - `getStatistics()`: Returns min, max, avg, count
 
 - **Thread Safety**: ReadWriteLock allows concurrent reads while ensuring exclusive writes

4. **Created DriverApplication.java** - Comprehensive demo with 5 scenarios:
 - Demo 1: Basic operations (add, query max, query at timestamp)
 - Demo 2: Out-of-order timestamps
 - Demo 3: Duplicate timestamps (updates)
 - Demo 4: Concurrent reads and writes (5 threads, 100 operations each)

## 3. Key Technical Concepts

### Commodity Prices Module Specific:
- **Dual Data Structure Pattern**: Using HashMap + TreeSet for different query optimizations
- **TreeSet**: Java's red-black tree implementation for sorted data with O(log N) operations
- **ConcurrentHashMap**: Thread-safe HashMap without locking entire map
- **ReadWriteLock**: Java concurrency mechanism allowing multiple concurrent reads but exclusive writes
- **Out-of-order Data Handling**: Accepting data points in any timestamp order
- **Update Semantics**: Replacing existing values when duplicate timestamps arrive
- **O(1) Max Queries**: Constant time max retrieval using TreeSet.first()
- **O(log N) Updates**: Logarithmic time insertions/removals in TreeSet

### General Project Patterns:
- **Maven Multi-Module Project**: Parent POM with multiple child modules
- **Immutable Objects**: Data classes with final fields
- **Builder Pattern**: Used in configuration objects across modules
- **Factory Pattern**: Used in some modules for object creation
- **Thread-Safe Collections**: ConcurrentHashMap, TreeSet with locks
- **ReadWriteLock Pattern**: Optimizing for read-heavy workloads

- **Event Sweep**: Minimum courts calculation

## 4. Relevant Files and Code

### **commodity-prices-lld/pom.xml**
- Maven configuration for the new module
- Dependencies: JUnit 4.13.2
- Exec plugin configured with mainClass: com.commodityprices.DriverApplication
- Java 11 target

### **commodity-prices-lld/src/main/java/com/commodityprices/PriceDataPoint.java**
- Immutable data class representing a price data point
- Fields: `long timestamp`, `double price`
- Validation in constructor (non-negative values)
- Implements Comparable for TreeSet ordering:
```java
@Override
public int compareTo(PriceDataPoint other) {
 // First compare by price (descending), then by timestamp (ascending)
 int priceCompare = Double.compare(other.price, this.price);
 if (priceCompare != 0) {
 return priceCompare;
 }
 return Long.compare(this.timestamp, other.timestamp);
}
```

### **commodity-prices-lld/src/main/java/com/commodityprices/CommodityPriceTracker.java**
- Main tracking system with dual data structure approach
- **Data Structures**:
```java
private final Map<Long, Double> timestampToPriceMap; // O(1) lookups
private final TreeSet<PriceDataPoint> pricesSortedByValue; // O(log N) insert, O(1) max
private final ReadWriteLock lock; // Concurrent reads
```

- **Update Method** (handles duplicates):
```java
public void update(long timestamp, double price) {
 lock.writeLock().lock();
 try {
 Double oldPrice = timestampToPriceMap.get(timestamp);
 
 if (oldPrice != null) {
 // Remove old data point from TreeSet
 pricesSortedByValue.remove(new PriceDataPoint(timestamp, oldPrice));
 }
 
 // Add new data point
 timestampToPriceMap.put(timestamp, price);
 pricesSortedByValue.add(new PriceDataPoint(timestamp, price));
 } finally {
 lock.writeLock().unlock();
 }
}
```

- **Get Max Price** (O(1)):
```java
public Double getMaxPrice() {
 lock.readLock().lock();
 try {
 if (pricesSortedByValue.isEmpty()) {
 return null;
 }
 return pricesSortedByValue.first().getPrice();
 } finally {
 lock.readLock().unlock();
 }
}
```

- **PriceStatistics Inner Class**: Returns count, min, max, avg

### **commodity-prices-lld/src/main/java/com/commodityprices/DriverApplication.java**
- Comprehensive demo application with 5 scenarios
- Demo 1: Basic operations (add 4 points, query max, query at timestamp)
- Demo 2: Out-of-order timestamps (adds timestamps 5000, 2000, 8000, 1000, 4000)
- Demo 3: Duplicate timestamps showing updates
- Demo 4: Concurrent operations with 5 threads, 100 operations each
- Demo 5: Real-time streaming simulation with 10 data points

### **pom.xml** (Parent - Not Yet Updated)

### **README.md** (Main - Not Yet Updated)

## 5. Problem Solving

**Successfully Solved:**

1. **Efficient Max Price Queries**: Used TreeSet to maintain sorted order by price, allowing O(1) max retrieval via `first()` method.

2. **Fast Timestamp Lookups**: Used HashMap for O(1) timestamp-to-price lookups.

3. **Duplicate Timestamp Handling**: When updating existing timestamp:
 - Remove old PriceDataPoint from TreeSet
 - Update HashMap
 - Add new PriceDataPoint to TreeSet

4. **Out-of-order Timestamps**: TreeSet automatically maintains sorted order regardless of insertion order.

5. **Thread Safety for Frequent Reads/Writes**: 
 - ReadWriteLock allows multiple concurrent readers
 - Writers get exclusive access
 - Optimized for read-heavy workloads

6. **Maintaining Consistency**: Both data structures (HashMap and TreeSet) are updated atomically within write lock to prevent inconsistencies.

**Design Decisions:**

1. **Why TreeSet over PriorityQueue**: TreeSet allows O(log N) removal of arbitrary elements (needed for updates), while PriorityQueue only supports O(log N) removal of the head.

2. **Why ConcurrentHashMap**: Provides thread-safe operations without locking entire map, though ReadWriteLock is still used for cross-structure consistency.

3. **Why ReadWriteLock over synchronized**: Allows multiple concurrent readers, improving performance for read-heavy workloads.

Commodity Prices

The timestamps in the stream can be out of order, or there can be duplicate timestamps, we need to update the commodityPrice at that particular timestamp if an entry for the timestamp already exists

### **popular-content-lld/src/main/java/com/popularcontent/ContentAction.java**

```java
public enum ContentAction {
 INCREASE_POPULARITY, // +1 (likes, comments)
 DECREASE_POPULARITY // -1 (spam removal)
}
```

### **popular-content-lld/src/main/java/com/popularcontent/PopularContentTracker.java**
- Main tracking system with dual data structure approach
- **Data Structures**:
```java
private final Map<Integer, Integer> contentPopularity; // contentId → popularity
private final TreeMap<Integer, Set<Integer>> popularityToContents; // popularity → contentIds (descending)
private final ReadWriteLock lock; // Thread safety
```

- **Constructor**:
```java
public PopularContentTracker() {
 this.contentPopularity = new HashMap<>();
 this.popularityToContents = new TreeMap<>(Collections.reverseOrder());
 this.lock = new ReentrantReadWriteLock();
}
```

- **Process Action Method** (handles increase/decrease and automatic cleanup):
```java
public void processAction(int contentId, ContentAction action) {
 lock.writeLock().lock();
 try {
 int currentPopularity = contentPopularity.getOrDefault(contentId, 0);
 int newPopularity = (action == ContentAction.INCREASE_POPULARITY) 
 ? currentPopularity + 1 
 : currentPopularity - 1;
 
 // Remove from old popularity bucket
 if (currentPopularity != 0) {
 Set<Integer> oldBucket = popularityToContents.get(currentPopularity);
 if (oldBucket != null) {
 oldBucket.remove(contentId);
 if (oldBucket.isEmpty()) {
 popularityToContents.remove(currentPopularity);
 }
 }
 }
 
 // Update or remove content
 if (newPopularity <= 0) {
 contentPopularity.remove(contentId); // Automatic cleanup
 } else {
 contentPopularity.put(contentId, newPopularity);
 popularityToContents
 .computeIfAbsent(newPopularity, k -> new HashSet<>())
 .add(contentId);
 }
 } finally {
 lock.writeLock().unlock();
 }
}
```

- **Get Most Popular Method** (O(1)):
```java
public int getMostPopular() {
 lock.readLock().lock();
 try {
 if (popularityToContents.isEmpty()) {
 return -1;
 }
 Map.Entry<Integer, Set<Integer>> highestEntry = popularityToContents.firstEntry();
 if (highestEntry == null || highestEntry.getValue().isEmpty()) {
 return -1;
 }
 return highestEntry.getValue().iterator().next();
 } finally {
 lock.readLock().unlock();
 }
}
```

## 5. Problem Solving

**Successfully Solved:**

1. **Efficient Most Popular Queries**: Used TreeMap with reverse order to maintain sorted order by popularity (descending), allowing O(1) max retrieval via `firstEntry()` method.

2. **Fast Content Lookups**: Used HashMap for O(1) content ID to popularity lookups.

3. **Handling Popularity Changes**: When updating content popularity:
 - Remove content from old popularity bucket in TreeMap
 - Update HashMap
 - Add content to new popularity bucket in TreeMap
 - If new popularity ≤ 0, remove from both structures (automatic cleanup)

4. **Multiple Contents with Same Popularity**: TreeMap maps popularity to Set<Integer> of content IDs, allowing multiple contents to have the same popularity. `getMostPopular()` returns any one from the set.

5. **Thread Safety for Frequent Reads/Writes**: 
 - ReadWriteLock allows multiple concurrent readers
 - Writers get exclusive access
 - Optimized for read-heavy workloads

6. **Maintaining Consistency**: Both data structures (HashMap and TreeMap) are updated atomically within write lock to prevent inconsistencies.

**Design Decisions:**

1. **Why TreeMap over PriorityQueue**: TreeMap allows O(log N) removal of arbitrary elements (needed for updates), while PriorityQueue only supports O(log N) removal of the head. Also, TreeMap with reverse order gives instant access to highest popularity.

2. **Why HashMap + TreeMap**: HashMap alone would require O(N) to find max popularity. TreeMap alone would require maintaining content-to-popularity mapping separately. Both together provide optimal performance.

3. **Why ReadWriteLock over synchronized**: Allows multiple concurrent readers, improving performance for read-heavy workloads.

4. **Automatic Cleanup**: Removing content when popularity ≤ 0 keeps memory usage optimal and ensures getMostPopular() only returns active content.

All modules include comprehensive documentation (README.md and INTERVIEW_STRATEGY.md), extensive test coverage, and demo applications. The project currently has 287 tests passing across all 8 modules.

## 2. Current Work

The user requested creation of a new module for the "Middleware Router" design interview question. The problem involves implementing a middleware router for web services that routes requests based on path patterns and returns different strings (handlers). The question has multiple scale-up parts:
- Basic path-based routing
- Scale Up 1: Wildcards using ordered checking
- Scale Up 2: Path parameters (PathParams)

**Work Completed So Far:**

1. **Created module structure** (middleware-router-lld/pom.xml):
 - Maven module configuration

2. **Created Route.java** - Represents a route with pattern matching:
 - **Fields**: pattern, handler, priority, hasWildcard, hasPathParams, pathParamNames, compiledPattern
 - **Pattern compilation**: Converts path patterns to regex
 - Path params (`:param`) → regex groups `([^/]+)`
 - Wildcards (`*`) → regex `.*`
 - **Priority calculation**: Automatic priority based on specificity
 - Exact paths: priority 0 (highest)
 - Path params: priority 100 - (path segments * 10)
 - Wildcards: priority 200 - wildcard index
 - **Methods**:
 - `matches(String path)`: Checks if route matches path using compiled regex
 - `extractPathParams(String path)`: Extracts path parameter values into a map
 - `calculateDefaultPriority()`: Calculates priority based on pattern specificity

3. **Created RouteMatch.java** - Represents a successful route match:
 - **Fields**: handler (String), pathParams (Map<String, String>), route (Route)
 - **Methods**:

 - `getPathParams()`: Returns unmodifiable map of path parameters
 - `getPathParam(String name)`: Gets a specific path parameter value
 - `hasPathParam(String name)`: Checks if a path parameter exists
 - Immutable design with defensive copying

4. **Created MiddlewareRouter.java** - Main routing system:
 - **Data Structures**:
 - `List<Route> routes`: Stores all registered routes
 - `ReadWriteLock lock`: For thread safety
 - `boolean autoSort`: Whether to auto-sort routes by priority
 - **Key Methods**:
 - `register(String pattern, String handler)`: Registers a route with auto-calculated priority
 - `register(String pattern, String handler, int priority)`: Registers with explicit priority
 - `route(String path)`: Routes a path and returns handler string (simple version)
 - `routeWithParams(String path)`: Routes and returns RouteMatch with path params
 - `removeRoute(String pattern)`: Removes routes by pattern
 - `clear()`: Clears all routes
 - `getRouteCount()`: Returns number of routes
 - `getRoutes()`: Returns copy of all routes
 - `getStatistics()`: Returns statistics about route types
 - **Thread Safety**: ReadWriteLock allows concurrent reads, exclusive writes

## 3. Key Technical Concepts

### Middleware Router Specific:
- **Path Pattern Matching**: Converting path patterns to regex for flexible matching
- **Wildcards**: Using `*` to match any sequence of characters
- **Path Parameters**: Using `:paramName` syntax to extract dynamic segments
- **Priority-based Routing**: Lower priority numbers = higher priority, more specific routes first
- **First-match Strategy**: Return first matching route in priority order
- **Regex Compilation**: Pre-compiling patterns for performance
- **Named Capture Groups**: Extracting path parameter values using regex groups

### General Project Patterns:
- **Maven Multi-Module Project**: Parent POM with multiple child modules
- **Immutable Objects**: Data classes with final fields where appropriate

- **ReadWriteLock Pattern**: Optimizing for read-heavy workloads
- **JUnit 4**: Testing framework used across all modules
- **Java 11**: Target version for all modules
- **Defensive Copying**: Returning unmodifiable collections from getters

### Design Patterns:
- **Strategy Pattern**: Different routing strategies (exact, wildcard, path params)
- **Builder Pattern**: Used in some modules for complex object creation
- **Factory Pattern**: Used in some modules for object creation

## 4. Relevant Files and Code

### **middleware-router-lld/src/main/java/com/middlewarerouter/Route.java**
- Represents a route with pattern, handler, and priority
- **Pattern Compilation**:
```java
private Pattern compilePattern(String pattern) {
 String regex = pattern;
 
 // Extract path parameter names
 Pattern paramPattern = Pattern.compile(":([a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9_]*)");
 Matcher matcher = paramPattern.matcher(pattern);
 while (matcher.find()) {
 pathParamNames.add(matcher.group(1));
 }
 
 // Convert path params to regex groups
 regex = regex.replaceAll(":([a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9_]*)", "([^/]+)");
 
 // Convert wildcards to regex
 regex = regex.replace("*", ".*");
 
 // Exact match
 regex = "^" + regex + "$";
 
 return Pattern.compile(regex);
}
```

- **Priority Calculation**:
```java
private static int calculateDefaultPriority(String pattern) {
 int priority = 0;
 
 // Exact paths have highest priority
 if (!pattern.contains("*") && !pattern.contains(":")) {
 return 0;
 }
 
 // Path params have medium priority
 if (pattern.contains(":")) {
 priority = 100;
 priority -= pattern.split("/").length * 10;
 }
 
 // Wildcards have lowest priority
 if (pattern.contains("*")) {
 priority = 200;
 int wildcardIndex = pattern.indexOf("*");
 priority -= wildcardIndex;
 }
 
 return priority;
}
```

- **Path Parameter Extraction**:
```java
public Map<String, String> extractPathParams(String path) {
 Map<String, String> params = new HashMap<>();
 
 if (!hasPathParams) {
 return params;
 }
 
 Matcher matcher = compiledPattern.matcher(path);
 if (matcher.matches()) {
 for (int i = 0; i < pathParamNames.size(); i++) {
 params.put(pathParamNames.get(i), matcher.group(i + 1));
 }
 }
 
 return params;
}
```

### **middleware-router-lld/src/main/java/com/middlewarerouter/RouteMatch.java** (Currently Open)
- Represents a successful route match with handler and path parameters
- **Constructor**:

```java
public RouteMatch(String handler, Map<String, String> pathParams, Route route) {
 this.handler = handler;
 this.pathParams = pathParams != null ? pathParams : Collections.emptyMap();
 this.route = route;
}
```

- **Key Methods**:
```java
public String getHandler() {
 return handler;
}

public Map<String, String> getPathParams() {
 return Collections.unmodifiableMap(pathParams);
}

public String getPathParam(String name) {
 return pathParams.get(name);
}

public boolean hasPathParam(String name) {
 return pathParams.containsKey(name);
}
```

### **middleware-router-lld/src/main/java/com/middlewarerouter/MiddlewareRouter.java**
- Main routing system with thread-safe route registration and matching
- **Route Registration**:
```java
public void register(String pattern, String handler) {
 lock.writeLock().lock();
 try {
 Route route = new Route(pattern, handler);
 routes.add(route);
 if (autoSort) {
 sortRoutes();
 }
 } finally {
 lock.writeLock().unlock();
 }
}
```

- **Route Matching with Path Params**:
```java
public RouteMatch routeWithParams(String path) {
 if (path == null) {
 return null;
 }
 
 lock.readLock().lock();
 try {
 for (Route route : routes) {
 if (route.matches(path)) {
 Map<String, String> pathParams = route.extractPathParams(path);
 return new RouteMatch(route.getHandler(), pathParams, route);
 }
 }
 return null;
 } finally {
 lock.readLock().unlock();
 }
}
```

- **Route Sorting**:
```java
private void sortRoutes() {
 routes.sort(Comparator.comparingInt(Route::getPriority));
}
```

## 5. Problem Solving

**Successfully Solved:**

1. **Pattern Matching with Multiple Types**: Designed a unified system that handles exact paths, wildcards, and path parameters using regex compilation.

2. **Priority-based Ordering**: Implemented automatic priority calculation based on pattern specificity:
 - Exact paths get highest priority (0)
 - Path params get medium priority (100 - specificity)
 - Wildcards get lowest priority (200 - specificity)

3. **Path Parameter Extraction**: Used regex named groups to extract dynamic path segments and map them to parameter names.

4. **Thread Safety**: Implemented ReadWriteLock to allow concurrent route matching while ensuring safe route registration.

5. **First-match Strategy**: Routes are sorted by priority, and the first matching route wins, ensuring predictable behavior.

**Design Decisions:**

1. **Why Regex for Pattern Matching**: Provides flexible, powerful matching for wildcards and path params with good performance when pre-compiled.

2. **Why Priority-based Ordering**: Ensures more specific routes are checked first, preventing wildcards from shadowing exact matches.

3. **Why ReadWriteLock**: Allows multiple concurrent route lookups (read-heavy workload) while ensuring safe route registration.

4. **Why Immutable RouteMatch**: Prevents accidental modification of match results, thread-safe by design.

<summary>
# Conversation Summary

## 1. Previous Conversation

The user has been building a comprehensive collection of low-level design implementations for interview preparation in a Maven multi-module project called "AtlassianLowLevelDesign". Throughout the conversation, the user has requested the creation of multiple modules, each solving a specific system design interview question:

1. **Logging Library (logging-lld)**: A comprehensive logging system with sync/async loggers, multiple sinks, and log levels (43 tests passing).

2. **Rate Limiter (ratelimiter-lld)**: Implementation of 4 rate limiting algorithms - Token Bucket, Sliding Window Log, Fixed Window Counter, and Sliding Window Counter (20 tests passing).

3. **Agent Ranking System (agent-ranking-lld)**: A customer support agent ranking system based on average ratings with real-time ranking updates, thread-safe operations, and department-wise leaderboards (31 tests passing).

4. **Organization Hierarchy (org-hierarchy-lld)**: A system to find the closest common parent group for employees in an organization hierarchy, implementing Lowest Common Ancestor (LCA) algorithm in a DAG structure (27 tests passing).

5. **Tennis Court Booking System (tennis-court-lld)**: The "Expanding Tennis Club" interview question implementation covering minimum court allocation with greedy algorithm and maintenance handling (60 tests passing).

6. **Commodity Prices Tracker (commodity-prices-lld)**: Real-time commodity price tracking with dual data structure design (HashMap + TreeSet) for O(1) max price queries and O(log N) updates (42 tests passing).

7. **Popular Content Tracker (popular-content-lld)**: Real-time content popularity tracking with dual data structure approach (HashMap + TreeMap) for O(1) most popular queries and O(log N) updates (24 tests passing).

8. **Customer Satisfaction System (customer-satisfaction-lld)**: Customer support agent rating system with comprehensive analytics covering all 5 parts (a-e) of the interview question - basic ratings, tie-breaking strategies, monthly performance tracking, export in multiple formats (CSV, JSON, XML), and unsorted/totals features (40 tests passing).

9. **Middleware Router (middleware-router-lld)**: A middleware router for web services that supports exact path matching, wildcard patterns (`*`), and path parameter extraction (`:param`) with priority-based routing (40 tests passing).

All modules include comprehensive documentation (README.md and INTERVIEW_STRATEGY.md), extensive test coverage, and demo applications.

## 2. Current Work

The user requested creation of a new module for the "Game of Snakes" design interview question. The problem involves implementing the classic Snake game with the following requirements:

**Base Requirements:**
- Snake can move up, down, left, right in a 2D board of arbitrary size
- Every time `moveSnake()` is called, the snake moves in a direction
- Initial size is 3
- Snake grows by 1 every 5 moves
- Game ends when snake hits itself or goes out of bounds

**Changes:**
- Change #1: Make scale-up 2 optional (removed)
- Change #2: Add new optional scale-up - snake grows when it eats food rather than every 5 moves. Food is dropped at a random position on the board.

**Work Completed:**

1. **Created module structure** (snake-game-lld/pom.xml):
 - Maven module configuration
 - JUnit 4.13.2 dependency
 - Exec plugin configured with mainClass: com.snakegame.DriverApplication

2. **Created Direction.java** - Enum for 4 directions:
 - UP(0, -1), DOWN(0, 1), LEFT(-1, 0), RIGHT(1, 0)
 - Methods: getDx(), getDy(), opposite()

3. **Created Position.java** - Immutable position class:
 - Fields: x, y
 - Methods: move(Direction), isWithinBounds(width, height)
 - Proper equals/hashCode implementation

4. **Created GrowthStrategy interface** - Strategy pattern for growth:
 - Method: shouldGrow(moveCount, ateFoodThisMove)
 - Method: reset()

5. **Created FixedIntervalGrowthStrategy** - Default growth strategy:
 - Grows every N moves (default 5)
 - Configurable interval

6. **Created FoodGrowthStrategy** - Optional scale-up:
 - Grows only when eating food
 - Ignores move count

7. **Created SnakeGame.java** - Main game class:
 - **Data Structures**:
 - `Deque<Position> snake`: Snake body (head at last, tail at first)
 - `Set<Position> snakeBody`: For O(1) collision detection
 - `Position food`: Current food position (if using food system)
 - **Key Methods**:
 - `moveSnake(Direction)`: Moves snake, checks collisions, handles growth
 - `isGameOver()`: Returns game over status
 - `getSnakeLength()`: Returns current length
 - `reset()`: Resets game to initial state
 - **Growth Logic**: 
 - Increment move count first
 - Check if should grow based on strategy
 - If not growing, remove tail before checking collision
 - Check collision with snake body
 - Add new head
 - If ate food and growing, spawn new food
 - **Collision Detection**:
 - Boundary collision: Check if new head is within bounds
 - Self-collision: Check if new head is in snakeBody set
 - **Opposite Direction Prevention**: Prevents snake from moving in opposite direction (would immediately hit itself)

8. **Created DriverApplication.java** - Comprehensive demo with 5 scenarios:
 - Demo 1: Basic movement (RIGHT, DOWN)
 - Demo 2: Growth every 5 moves
 - Demo 3: Self-collision detection
 - Demo 4: Boundary collision detection
 - Demo 5: Food-based growth system

9. **Created comprehensive tests** (56 tests total):
 - **PositionTest** (12 tests): Movement, bounds checking, immutability
 - **DirectionTest** (3 tests): Direction deltas, opposite directions
 - **GrowthStrategyTest** (10 tests): Fixed interval and food growth strategies
 - **SnakeGameTest** (31 tests): Initialization, movement, growth, collisions, food system, reset

10. **Fixed bugs during testing**:
 - Fixed growth logic to increment move count before checking growth
 - Fixed collision detection to remove tail first if not growing
 - Fixed test cases to avoid boundary collisions during growth tests
 - Fixed self-collision test to create a proper collision scenario

11. **Successfully compiled and tested**:
 - All 56 tests passing
 - Demo application runs successfully
 - Module integrated into parent pom.xml

**Current Status**: The module is fully implemented and tested. The assistant was about to create README.md and INTERVIEW_STRATEGY.md documentation files when the summarization was requested.

## 3. Key Technical Concepts

### Snake Game Specific:
- **Deque for Snake Body**: Using LinkedList as Deque - head at last, tail at first for efficient add/remove
- **HashSet for Collision Detection**: O(1) lookup for checking if position is occupied
- **Strategy Pattern**: Different growth strategies (fixed interval vs food-based)
- **Immutable Position**: Position objects are immutable for safety
- **Direction Enum**: Encapsulates movement deltas (dx, dy)
- **Opposite Direction Prevention**: Prevents 180-degree turns that would cause immediate collision
- **Growth Mechanics**: Snake grows by not removing tail on growth moves
- **Collision Types**: Self-collision (hits own body) and boundary collision (out of bounds)
- **Food System**: Random food spawning on empty positions

### General Project Patterns:
- **Maven Multi-Module Project**: Parent POM with multiple child modules
- **Strategy Pattern**: GrowthStrategy interface with multiple implementations
- **Immutable Objects**: Position class with final fields
- **Defensive Copying**: getSnake() returns new LinkedList
- **JUnit 4**: Testing framework used across all modules
- **Java 11**: Target version for all modules
- **Builder Pattern**: Used in some modules for complex object creation

### Design Patterns:
- **Strategy Pattern**: GrowthStrategy interface for different growth mechanics
- **Enum Pattern**: Direction enum with behavior (opposite())
- **Immutable Value Objects**: Position class

## 4. Relevant Files and Code

### **snake-game-lld/pom.xml**

- Dependencies: JUnit 4.13.2

### **snake-game-lld/src/main/java/com/snakegame/Direction.java**
- Enum for four directions with delta values
```java
public enum Direction {
 UP(0, -1),
 DOWN(0, 1),
 LEFT(-1, 0),
 RIGHT(1, 0);
 
 public Direction opposite() {
 switch (this) {
 case UP: return DOWN;
 case DOWN: return UP;
 case LEFT: return RIGHT;
 case RIGHT: return LEFT;
 }
 }
}
```

### **snake-game-lld/src/main/java/com/snakegame/Position.java**
- Immutable position class with movement and bounds checking
```java
public class Position {
 private final int x;
 private final int y;
 
 public Position move(Direction direction) {
 return new Position(x + direction.getDx(), y + direction.getDy());
 }
 
 public boolean isWithinBounds(int width, int height) {
 return x >= 0 && x < width && y >= 0 && y < height;
 }
}
```

### **snake-game-lld/src/main/java/com/snakegame/GrowthStrategy.java**
- Strategy interface for growth mechanics
```java
public interface GrowthStrategy {
 boolean shouldGrow(int moveCount, boolean ateFoodThisMove);
 void reset();
}
```

### **snake-game-lld/src/main/java/com/snakegame/FixedIntervalGrowthStrategy.java**
- Default growth strategy (every 5 moves)
```java
public class FixedIntervalGrowthStrategy implements GrowthStrategy {
 private final int interval;
 
 public FixedIntervalGrowthStrategy() {
 this(5);
 }
 
 @Override
 public boolean shouldGrow(int moveCount, boolean ateFoodThisMove) {
 return moveCount > 0 && moveCount % interval == 0;
 }
}
```

### **snake-game-lld/src/main/java/com/snakegame/FoodGrowthStrategy.java**
- Food-based growth strategy (optional scale-up)
```java
public class FoodGrowthStrategy implements GrowthStrategy {
 @Override
 public boolean shouldGrow(int moveCount, boolean ateFoodThisMove) {
 return ateFoodThisMove;
 }
}
```

### **snake-game-lld/src/main/java/com/snakegame/SnakeGame.java**
- Main game class with complete game logic
- **Critical Movement Logic**:
```java
public boolean moveSnake(Direction direction) {
 // Prevent opposite direction
 if (snake.size() > 1 && direction == currentDirection.opposite()) {
 direction = currentDirection;
 }
 
 Position newHead = currentHead.move(direction);
 
 // Check bounds
 if (!newHead.isWithinBounds(width, height)) {
 gameOver = true;
 return false;
 }
 
 // Increment move count
 moveCount++;
 
 // Check if ate food
 boolean ateFood = useFoodSystem && newHead.equals(food);
 
 // Determine if should grow
 boolean shouldGrow = growthStrategy.shouldGrow(moveCount, ateFood);
 
 // Remove tail if not growing
 Position removedTail = null;
 if (!shouldGrow) {
 removedTail = snake.removeFirst();
 snakeBody.remove(removedTail);
 }
 
 // Check self-collision
 if (snakeBody.contains(newHead)) {
 gameOver = true;
 if (removedTail != null) {
 snake.addFirst(removedTail);
 snakeBody.add(removedTail);
 }
 return false;
 }
 
 // Add new head
 snake.addLast(newHead);
 snakeBody.add(newHead);
 
 // Spawn new food if ate
 if (shouldGrow && ateFood) {
 spawnFood();
 }
 
 return true;
}
```

### **snake-game-lld/src/main/java/com/snakegame/DriverApplication.java** (Currently Open)
- Comprehensive demo application with 5 scenarios
- Demonstrates all features: basic movement, growth, collisions, food system

### **snake-game-lld/src/test/java/com/snakegame/SnakeGameTest.java**

### **pom.xml** (Parent - Updated)

## 5. Problem Solving

**Successfully Solved:**

1. **Growth Logic Bug**: Initially the growth logic was checking growth after removing the tail, which caused incorrect behavior. Fixed by:
 - Incrementing move count first
 - Checking if should grow
 - Removing tail only if not growing
 - Then checking collision

2. **Self-Collision Detection**: Initial implementation had issues with collision detection. Fixed by:
 - Removing tail first if not growing (so collision check is accurate)
 - Checking if new head is in snakeBody set
 - Restoring tail if collision detected (to maintain game state)

3. **Test Failures**: Tests were failing because:
 - **Growth tests**: Snake was moving in straight line and hitting boundary before completing all moves. Fixed by alternating directions.
 - **Self-collision test**: Snake wasn't long enough to hit itself. Fixed by growing snake first (10 moves to get length 5), then creating a box pattern that causes collision.

4. **Opposite Direction Prevention**: Implemented logic to prevent snake from moving in opposite direction, which would cause immediate self-collision.

**Design Decisions:**

1. **Why Deque for Snake**: Efficient O(1) add/remove at both ends for head and tail operations.

2. **Why HashSet for Body**: O(1) collision detection instead of O(N) linear search.

3. **Why Strategy Pattern for Growth**: Allows easy switching between fixed interval and food-based growth without changing game logic.

4. **Why Immutable Position**: Thread-safe, prevents accidental modification, cleaner code.

5. **Why Remove Tail Before Collision Check**: When not growing, the tail position will be vacated, so it shouldn't count as a collision.

I will continue the conversation from this point."},{"id":1,"type":5,"content":"","tool_use":{"tool_use_id":"toolu_vrtx_01TbwQ1yEJi21qo6oPSeZi6v","tool_name":"save-file","input_json":"{"instructions_reminder": "LIMIT THE FILE CONTENT TO AT MOST 300 LINES. IF MORE CONTENT NEEDS TO BE ADDED USE THE str-replace-editor TOOL TO EDIT THE FILE AFTER IT HAS BEEN CREATED.", "path": "snake-game-lld/README.md", "file_content": "# Snake Game\n\nA comprehensive implementation of the classic Snake game with configurable growth strategies, collision detection, and optional food system.\n\n## \ud83d\udccb Problem Statement\n\nImplement the base logic of the classic Snake game with the following requirements:\n\n### Core Requirements\n- Snake moves in 4 directions: UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT\n- Every time `moveSnake()` is called, the snake moves in the current direction\n- Initial snake size is 3\n- Snake grows by 1 every 5 moves (configurable)\n- Game ends when snake hits itself or goes out of bounds\n- Board is 2D with arbitrary size\n\n### Optional Scale-Up (Change #2)\n- Snake grows when it eats food rather than every N moves\n- Food is dropped at random positions on the board\n- New food spawns after current food is eaten\n\n## \ud83c\udfd7\ufe0f Architecture\n\n### Core Components\n\n```\nSnakeGame\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 Direction # Enum for UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 Position # Immutable (x, y) coordinate\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 GrowthStrategy # Interface for growth logic\n\u2502 \u251c\u2500\u2500 FixedIntervalGrowthStrategy # Grow every N moves\n\u2502 \u2514\u2500\u2500 FoodGrowthStrategy # Grow when eating food\n\u2514\u2500\u2500 SnakeGame # Main game logic\n```\n\n### Data Structures\n\n```java\nclass SnakeGame {\n Deque<Position> snake; // Snake body (head at end)\n Set<Position> snakeBody; // Fast collision detection\n Direction currentDirection; // Current movement direction\n GrowthStrategy growthStrategy; // Pluggable growth logic\n Position food; // Food position (optional)\n int moveCount; // Total moves made\n boolean gameOver; // Game state\n}\n```\n\n## \ud83d\ude80 Usage\n\n### Basic Game (Growth Every 5 Moves)\n\n```java\n// Create game with default settings (20x20 board, grow every 5 moves)\nSnakeGame game = new SnakeGame();\n\n// Move the snake\ngame.moveSnake(Direction.RIGHT);\ngame.moveSnake(Direction.DOWN);\ngame.moveSnake(Direction.LEFT);\n\n// Check game state\nSystem.out.println(\"Length: \" + game.getSnakeLength());\nSystem.out.println(\"Game Over: \" + game.isGameOver());\n```\n\n### Custom Board Size\n\n```java\n// Create 30x30 board\nSnakeGame game = new SnakeGame(30, 30);\n\n// Move and check\nwhile (!game.isGameOver()) {\n game.moveSnake(Direction.RIGHT);\n}\n```\n\n### Custom Growth Interval\n\n```java\n// Grow every 3 moves instead of 5\nSnakeGame game = new SnakeGame(20, 20, \n new FixedIntervalGrowthStrategy(3), false);\n\n// After 3 moves, snake will be length 4\nfor (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {\n game.moveSnake(Direction.RIGHT);\n}\nSystem.out.println(game.getSnakeLength()); // 4\n```\n\n### Food-Based Growth (Optional Scale-Up)\n\n```java\n// Create game with food system\nSnakeGame game = new SnakeGame(20, 20, \n new FoodGrowthStrategy(), true);\n\n// Snake only grows when it eats food\nPosition foodPos = game.getFood();\nSystem.out.println(\"Food at: \" + foodPos);\n\n// Move towards food\ngame.moveSnake(Direction.RIGHT);\n\n// Check if ate food\nif (game.getSnakeLength() > 3) {\n System.out.println(\"Ate food! New food at: \" + game.getFood());\n}\n```\n\n### Direction Control\n\n```java\nSnakeGame game = new SnakeGame();\n\n// Set direction before moving\ngame.setDirection(Direction.UP);\ngame.moveSnake(); // Moves up\n\n// Or specify direction in move\ngame.moveSnake(Direction.RIGHT);\n```\n\n### Game State\n\n```java\n// Get current state\nPosition head = game.getHead();\nPosition tail = game.getTail();\nint length = game.getSnakeLength();\nint moves = game.getMoveCount();\nboolean gameOver = game.isGameOver();\n\n// Get snake body\nDeque<Position> snake = game.getSnake();\n\n// Check position\nboolean occupied = game.isSnakeAt(new Position(5, 5));\n\n// Reset game\ngame.reset();\n```\n\n### Visual Board\n\n```java\n// Print the board\nString board = game.getBoardString();\nSystem.out.println(board);\n\n// Output:\n// . . . . . . . . . .\n// . . . . . . . . . .\n// . . . S S H . . . .\n// . . . . . . . . . .\n// . . . F . . . . . .\n//\n// H = Head, S = Snake body, F = Food, . = Empty\n```\n\n## \ud83d\udcca Algorithm Details\n\n### Movement Algorithm\n1. Increment move count\n2. Check if should grow (based on strategy)\n3. If not growing, remove tail\n4. Calculate new head position\n5. Check for collisions (boundary, self)\n6. Add new head\n7. If ate food, spawn new food\n\n**Time Complexity**: O(1) per move\n**Space Complexity**: O(N) where N = snake length\n\n### Collision Detection\n- **Boundary**: Check if new head is within `[0, width) x [0, height)`\n- **Self-collision**: Check if new head is in `snakeBody` set\n- Uses HashSet for O(1) collision checks\n\n### Growth Strategies\n\n**FixedIntervalGrowthStrategy**:\n- Grows every N moves (default 5)\n- `shouldGrow(moveCount, ateFood) = (moveCount % interval == 0)`\n\n**FoodGrowthStrategy**:\n- Grows only when eating food\n- `shouldGrow(moveCount, ateFood) = ateFood`\n\n### Food Spawning\n- Random position generation\n- Ensures food doesn't spawn on snake\n- O(1) expected time (with low snake density)\n- Handles full board gracefully\n\n## \ud83c\udfaf Design Decisions\n\n### 1. Deque for Snake Body\n- **Pros**: O(1) add/remove at both ends\n- **Cons**: O(N) for collision checks\n- **Solution**: Also maintain HashSet for O(1) collision checks\n\n### 2. Strategy Pattern for Growth\n- **Pros**: Easy to add new growth mechanics\n- **Cons**: Slight complexity overhead\n- **Decision**: Flexibility worth it for extensibility\n\n### 3. Immutable Position\n- **Pros**: Thread-safe, prevents bugs\n- **Cons**: More object creation\n- **Decision**: Safety and clarity worth it\n\n### 4. Prevent Opposite Direction\n- **Pros**: Prevents instant self-collision\n- **Cons**: Slightly less flexible\n- **Decision**: Matches classic Snake game behavior\n\n### 5. Separate Food System Flag\n- **Pros**: Can use FixedInterval without food clutter\n- **Cons**: Two parameters for configuration\n- **Decision**: Cleaner separation of concerns\n\n## \ud83e\uddea Testing\n\n### Test Coverage\n\n**SnakeGameTest** (31 tests):\n- Initialization (state, position, validation)\n- Movement (all 4 directions, multiple moves, opposite prevention)\n- Growth (intervals, custom intervals)\n- Collisions (all 4 boundaries, self-collision, post-game-over)\n- Food system (initialization, growth strategy)\n- Reset (normal, after game over)\n- Utilities (board string, position checks, defensive copying)\n\n**PositionTest** (12 tests):\n- Creation, movement in all directions\n- Boundary checking, equals/hashCode\n- Immutability\n\n**DirectionTest** (3 tests):\n- Direction deltas, opposite directions\n\n**GrowthStrategyTest** (10 tests):\n- Fixed interval (default, custom, validation)\n- Food growth (eating, ignoring moves)\n- Reset behavior\n\n### Run Tests\n\n```bash\n# Run all tests\nmvn test -pl snake-game-lld\n\n# Run with coverage\nmvn clean test jacoco:report -pl snake-game-lld\n```\n\n## \ud83c\udf93 Interview Tips\n\n### Key Points to Mention\n\n1. **Data Structure Choice**:\n - Deque for efficient add/remove\n - HashSet for O(1) collision detection\n - Trade-off: 2x space for better time complexity\n\n2. **Growth Strategies**:\n - Strategy pattern for flexibility\n - Easy to add new mechanics (e.g., shrink on obstacles)\n - Separates growth logic from movement logic\n\n3. **Collision Detection**:\n - Boundary check before self-collision\n - Remove tail before checking (if not growing)\n - Restore state on collision\n\n4. **Food System**:\n - Random generation with collision avoidance\n - Handles edge cases (full board)\n - Optional feature with clean separation\n\n5. **Direction Handling**:\n - Prevent opposite direction (instant death)\n - Maintain current direction\n - Validate input\n\n### Follow-up Questions\n\n**Q: How to optimize for very large snakes?**\n- Use spatial hashing for collision detection\n- Quadtree for food placement\n- Limit snake length or board size\n\n**Q: How to add obstacles?**\n- Add `Set<Position> obstacles`\n- Check collision with obstacles\n- Generate obstacles avoiding snake and food\n\n**Q: How to support multiple snakes?**\n- Create `Snake` class\n- List of snakes in game\n- Check collisions between snakes\n\n**Q: How to add power-ups?**\n- Create `PowerUp` interface\n- Different types (speed, invincibility, etc.)\n- Apply effects on collection\n\n**Q: How to implement AI?**\n- Pathfinding (A*, BFS) to food\n- Avoid walls and self\n- Consider snake length in decisions\n\n**Q: How to make it multiplayer?**\n- Separate `Snake` instances\n- Turn-based or real-time\n- Collision between snakes\n\n## \ud83d\ude80 Running the Demo\n\n```bash\n# Compile\nmvn clean compile -pl snake-game-lld\n\n# Run demo\nmvn exec:java -Dexec.mainClass=\"com.snakegame.DriverApplication\" \\\n -pl snake-game-lld\n\n# Run tests\nmvn test -pl snake-game-lld\n```\n\n## \ud83d\udcc8 Complexity Summary\n\n| Operation | Time | Space |\n|-----------|------|-------|\n| moveSnake() | O(1) | O(1) |\n| Collision check | O(1) | O(N) |\n| Food spawn | O(1) expected | O(1) |\n| reset() | O(N) | O(1) |\n| getBoardString() | O(W\u00d7H) | O(W\u00d7H) |\n\nWhere:\n- N = snake length\n- W = board width\n- H = board height\n\n## \ud83c\udfaf Real-World Applications\n\n- **Classic Games**: Nokia Snake, Slither.io\n- **AI Training**: Reinforcement learning environments\n- **Pathfinding**: Testing algorithms\n- **Game Development**: Learning game loops and state management\n- **Education**: Teaching data structures and algorithms\n\n---\n\n**Status**: \u2705 Production-ready implementation with comprehensive testing and documentation\n\n**Test Results**: 56/56 tests passing\n"}","mcp_server_name":"","mcp_tool_name":""}}],"status":"success","seen_state":"seen","timestamp":"2025-10-18T08:48:19.875Z"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"f1781a9c-f6a4-4dc8-9e4f-50900ebcbf11","timestamp":"2025-10-18T08:34:52.735Z","request_message":"","status":"success","seen_state":"unseen"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"cd0a8ba6-b956-488e-bde9-f8e54eb6e0bf","timestamp":"2025-10-18T08:36:02.250Z","request_message":"","status":"success","seen_state":"unseen"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"ee5044ce-9789-4154-981e-0235189c6a8f","timestamp":"2025-10-18T08:36:07.764Z","request_message":"","status":"success","seen_state":"unseen"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"c65ed56b-e034-4a63-a840-f322e0761cf9","timestamp":"2025-10-18T08:36:19.728Z","request_message":"","status":"success","seen_state":"unseen"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"e75b868c-e40b-48a1-b5ee-653d59b13e89","timestamp":"2025-10-18T08:36:24.941Z","request_message":"","status":"success","seen_state":"unseen"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"bdeb1c2d-7490-4f54-a1da-72caf1c7311a","timestamp":"2025-10-18T08:36:38.001Z","request_message":"","status":"success","seen_state":"unseen"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"fca43d12-d5e4-4145-8194-a8040b22cf15","timestamp":"2025-10-18T08:45:22.645Z","request_message":"","status":"success","seen_state":"unseen"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"3508146c-dc97-4e8c-9e31-5f7f0bbfd0a1","timestamp":"2025-10-18T08:45:34.292Z","request_message":"","status":"success","seen_state":"unseen"},{"request_id":"96bbb2d2-e8c2-40d9-ba9a-b1b184648e25","uuid":"1a05d324-2dae-467b-b6ed-2a9ee14f9f51","chatItemType":"agentic-checkpoint-delimiter","status":"success","fromTimestamp":1760774600313,"toTimestamp":1760777163124,"seen_state":"unseen"},{"chatItemType":"exchange-pointer","exchangeUuid":"fdd616e0-69b1-43bd-a770-c0dc955967e7","ti ## 3. Key Technical Concepts

### Cost Explorer Specific:
- **Proration Algorithm**: `(Monthly Cost × Days Active) / Total Days in Month`
- **Unit Year**: Calendar year of the current date
- **Plan Date Ranges**: startDate and endDate (null = ongoing)
- **Multiple Plans**: Support for multiple products and plan upgrades
- **Future vs Past Months**: Based on current date for estimation marking
- **Immutable Dates**: Thread-safe LocalDate usage

### AsyncLogger Threading Concepts:
- **Producer-Consumer Pattern**: Main thread produces, worker thread consumes
- **BlockingQueue**: Thread-safe queue with automatic blocking (ArrayBlockingQueue)
- **Worker Thread**: Background thread that processes messages asynchronously
- **AtomicBoolean**: Thread-safe flag for shutdown coordination
- **Poison Pill Pattern**: Special message to signal thread termination
- **Thread.start()**: Creates new thread and runs in parallel
- **Thread.join()**: Waits for thread to complete
- **Daemon vs Non-Daemon Threads**: Non-daemon ensures completion before JVM exit
- **InterruptedException Handling**: Restore interrupt status
- **Bounded Buffer**: Prevents memory overflow with fixed capacity queue
- **Backpressure**: put() blocks when queue is full
- **FIFO Ordering**: Queue preserves message order
- **Graceful Shutdown**: Wait for all messages to be processed

### General Project Patterns:
- **Maven Multi-Module Project**: Parent POM with multiple child modules
- **Immutable Objects**: Thread-safe, prevents accidental modification
- **Defensive Copying**: Return copies of internal collections
- **JUnit 4**: Testing framework
- **Java 11**: Target version
- **Builder Pattern**: Used for configuration objects

## 4. Relevant Files and Code

### **cost-explorer-lld/src/main/java/com/costexplorer/Plan.java**
Core subscription plan class with proration logic:
```java
public double getCostForMonth(int year, int month) {
 if (!isActiveInMonth(year, month)) {
 return 0.0;
 }
 
 LocalDate monthStart = LocalDate.of(year, month, 1);
 LocalDate monthEnd = monthStart.withDayOfMonth(monthStart.lengthOfMonth());
 
 LocalDate billingStart = startDate.isAfter(monthStart) ? startDate : monthStart;
 LocalDate billingEnd = (endDate != null && endDate.isBefore(monthEnd)) ? endDate : monthEnd;
 
 int totalDaysInMonth = monthStart.lengthOfMonth();
 int daysActive = (int) (billingEnd.toEpochDay() - billingStart.toEpochDay() + 1);
 
 return (monthlyCost * daysActive) / totalDaysInMonth;
}
```

### **cost-explorer-lld/src/main/java/com/costexplorer/CostExplorer.java**
Main cost calculation engine:

```java
public double getYearlyCost(int year) {
 double total = 0.0;
 for (int month = 1; month <= 12; month++) {
 total += getMonthlyCost(year, month);
 }
 return total;
}
```

### **logging-lld/src/main/java/com/loggingmc/logger/AsyncLogger.java** (Currently Open Context)
Asynchronous logger with background thread processing:

**Key Components:**
```java
private final BlockingQueue<LogMessage> messageQueue;
private final Thread workerThread;
private final AtomicBoolean running;
private static final LogMessage POISON_PILL = new LogMessage("", LogLevel.DEBUG);
```

**Thread Creation (Constructor):**
```java
public AsyncLogger(LoggerConfiguration config) {
 this.messageQueue = new ArrayBlockingQueue<>(config.getBufferSize());
 this.running = new AtomicBoolean(true);
 
 // Start background worker thread
 this.workerThread = new Thread(new LogWorker(), "AsyncLogger-" + name);
 this.workerThread.setDaemon(false);
 this.workerThread.start();
}
```

**Producer (Main Thread):**
```java
public void log(String message, LogLevel level) {
 LogMessage logMessage = new LogMessage(message, level);
 try {
 messageQueue.put(logMessage); // Blocks if queue is full
 } catch (InterruptedException e) {
 Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
 }
}
```

**Consumer (Worker Thread):**
```java
private class LogWorker implements Runnable {
 @Override
 public void run() {
 while (true) {
 try {
 LogMessage message = messageQueue.take(); // Blocks if queue is empty
 
 if (message == POISON_PILL) {
 break; // Exit loop
 }
 
 for (Sink sink : sinks) {
 sink.write(message, timestampFormat);
 }
 } catch (InterruptedException e) {
 Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
 break;
 }
 }
 }
}
```

**Graceful Shutdown:**
```java
public void shutdown() {
 if (!running.compareAndSet(true, false)) {
 return;
 }
 
 try {
 messageQueue.put(POISON_PILL); // Signal worker to stop
 workerThread.join(5000); // Wait for worker to finish
 
 if (workerThread.isAlive()) {
 workerThread.interrupt();
 }
 } catch (InterruptedException e) {
 Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
 }
 
 for (Sink sink : sinks) {
 sink.close();
 }
}
```

<summary>
# Summary of Conversation

## 1. Previous Conversation:
The user initially requested help with an LRU Cache implementation. I created a comprehensive LRU Cache module (`lru-cache-lld`) with:
- Complete Java implementation using HashMap + Doubly Linked List
- Detailed explanation document with ASCII diagrams showing how LRU cache works
- Step-by-step visual examples of cache operations
- Performance analysis and real-world use cases

After completing the LRU Cache, the user then requested a File System design with specific functional and non-functional requirements.

## 2. Current Work:
I am currently implementing a comprehensive in-memory File System module (`file-system-lld`) with the following requirements:

**Functional Requirements:**
- mkdir/ls/stat operations
- create/read/write (append|overwrite) files
- move/rename and delete operations
- resolve absolute/relative paths with . and ..
- set/get permissions; maintain size/ctime/mtime

**Non-Functional Requirements:**
- Thread-safe operations via per-path locks
- Atomic rename within directory tree
- Efficient directory lookups (hash map)
- Path normalization & validation

**Design Patterns Used:**
- Composite pattern for Directory/File tree
- Visitor pattern for traversal (size/permissions)
- Command pattern for mutating operations
- Iterator for ls/pagination
- Proxy/Decorator for permission checks
- Consistent lock ordering to avoid deadlocks

**Progress So Far:**
I have created the following components:

1. **Core classes** (Composite Pattern):
 - `Permission.java` - Unix-style permission system
 - `FileSystemNode.java` - Abstract base class for files and directories
 - `File.java` - File implementation with content storage
 - `Directory.java` - Directory implementation with ConcurrentHashMap for children
 - `FileStat.java` - File statistics (similar to Unix stat)
 - `PathResolver.java` - Path normalization and resolution with . and .. support

2. **Visitor Pattern**:
 - `NodeVisitor.java` - Visitor interface
 - `SizeCalculatorVisitor.java` - Calculate total size of directory tree
 - `PermissionUpdaterVisitor.java` - Recursively update permissions

3. **Locking Mechanism**:
 - `PathLockManager.java` - Per-path locks with consistent ordering to prevent deadlocks

4. **Main FileSystem Class**:
 - `FileSystem.java` - Complete implementation with all required operations (588 lines)

5. **Comprehensive Tests**:
 - `FileSystemTest.java` - 516 lines of JUnit tests covering all functionality including thread-safety tests

## 3. Key Technical Concepts:
- **Composite Pattern**: FileSystemNode as abstract base, File and Directory as concrete implementations
- **Visitor Pattern**: For tree traversal operations (size calculation, permission updates)
- **Thread Safety**: ReentrantReadWriteLock per path with consistent lock ordering (sorted paths) to prevent deadlocks
- **Path Resolution**: Normalization of paths with . (current dir) and .. (parent dir), prevention of traversal beyond root
- **Permission System**: Unix-style octal permissions (e.g., 0644, 0755) with read/write/execute bits
- **Atomic Operations**: Move/rename operations use multiple locks acquired in sorted order
- **ConcurrentHashMap**: Used in Directory for thread-safe child storage
- **Metadata Tracking**: Creation time (ctime) and modification time (mtime) for all nodes

## 4. Relevant Files and Code:

### Core Files Created:

- **`file-system-lld/src/main/java/com/filesystem/core/Permission.java`**
 - Unix-style permission bits (owner/group/others with read/write/execute)
 - Default permissions: 0644 for files, 0755 for directories
 - Permission checking methods: canRead(), canWrite(), canExecute()

- **`file-system-lld/src/main/java/com/filesystem/core/FileSystemNode.java`**
 - Abstract base class with name, permission, creationTime, modificationTime, parent
 - Abstract methods: isDirectory(), getSize(), accept(NodeVisitor)
 - Path building: getFullPath() constructs absolute path from root

- **`file-system-lld/src/main/java/com/filesystem/core/File.java`**
 - Content stored in StringBuilder
 - Methods: read(), write(data, append), overwrite(), append(), clear()
 - Permission checks before read/write operations

- **`file-system-lld/src/main/java/com/filesystem/core/Directory.java`**
 - Children stored in ConcurrentHashMap<String, FileSystemNode>
 - Methods: addChild(), removeChild(), getChild(), listChildren(), isEmpty()
 - Recursive size calculation by summing all children

- **`file-system-lld/src/main/java/com/filesystem/core/PathResolver.java`**
 - normalize(path): Resolves . and .. components, prevents root traversal
 - resolve(basePath, relativePath): Combines paths
 - split(path): Returns path components as list
 - getParent(path), getName(path): Path manipulation
 - validatePathComponent(): Checks for invalid characters and reserved names

- **`file-system-lld/src/main/java/com/filesystem/lock/PathLockManager.java`**
 - ConcurrentHashMap<String, ReentrantReadWriteLock> for per-path locks
 - acquireWriteLocks(String... paths): Sorts paths before locking to prevent deadlocks
 - withReadLock(), withWriteLock(), withWriteLocks(): Functional interface wrappers

- **`file-system-lld/src/main/java/com/filesystem/FileSystem.java`**
 - Main API with all operations:
 - mkdir(path, createParents), ls(path), lsDetailed(path), stat(path)
 - createFile(path), read(path), write(path, content, append)
 - move(sourcePath, destPath), rename(path, newName), delete(path, recursive)
 - setPermission(path, permission), getPermission(path)
 - exists(path), isDirectory(path), isFile(path)
 - changeDirectory(path), getCurrentWorkingDirectory()
 - getSize(path), tree(path)
 - Thread-safe operations using PathLockManager
 - Current working directory support for relative paths

- **`file-system-lld/src/test/java/com/filesystem/FileSystemTest.java`**
 - 516 lines of comprehensive tests
 - Tests for all CRUD operations
 - Path resolution tests (absolute, relative, ., ..)
 - Permission tests (read/write restrictions)
 - Concurrent operation tests (thread safety, no deadlocks)
 - Edge case tests (cannot delete root, move into itself, etc.)

### Key Code Patterns:

**Thread-safe operation pattern:**
```java
public String read(String path) {
 String normalizedPath = resolvePath(path);
 return lockManager.withReadLock(normalizedPath, () -> {
 FileSystemNode node = navigateToNode(normalizedPath);
 // ... operation
 return result;
 });
}
```

**Atomic move with multiple locks:**
```java
lockManager.withWriteLocks(() -> {
 // Perform atomic move operation
 sourceParent.removeChild(sourceNode.getName());
 sourceNode.setName(destName);
 destParent.addChild(sourceNode);
 return null;
}, normalizedSource, normalizedDest);
```

**Path normalization:**
```java
public static String normalize(String path) {
 Deque<String> stack = new ArrayDeque<>();
 for (String part : parts) {
 if (part.equals("..")) {
 if (!stack.isEmpty()) stack.pop();
 else if (!isAbsolute) throw new IllegalArgumentException("Path traversal beyond root");
 } else if (!part.isEmpty() && !part.equals(".")) {
 validatePathComponent(part);
 stack.push(part);
 }
 }
 // Build normalized path from stack
}
```

## 5. Problem Solving:
- **Deadlock Prevention**: Implemented consistent lock ordering by sorting paths alphabetically before acquiring locks
- **Path Traversal Security**: PathResolver prevents traversal beyond root with .. notation
- **Atomic Operations**: Move/rename operations acquire multiple locks in sorted order for atomicity
- **Thread Safety**: All operations use appropriate read/write locks via PathLockManager
- **Permission Enforcement**: File and Directory classes check permissions before allowing operations
- **Test Issue**: Fixed a str-replace-editor error by viewing the file first to get exact line numbers and content
